Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: P2C2--Multi-Site Paleo-Reconstruction of Missouri River Streamflows from Tree Ring Data
Award.AbstractNarration:
Modern records of gaged flow for major rivers are limited to the last 120 years, at most. These records, which reflect average annual flows as well as periods of drought, have been used to allocate water resources and plan for future uses. Tree-ring based reconstructions of streamflow have been used to extend records back in time. The most well-known of these, for the Colorado River, showed that the period of flow used to allocate the basin's water supplies in the 1920s was one of the wettest period of flow in the past five centuries. Reconstructions of flow for other basins, such as the Sacramento River, have shown that drought much longer than any in the gage records have occurred over past centuries.

This research will use centuries-long tree ring records to reconstruct streamflow for the Missouri River Basin for gages from the headwaters to the confluence with the Mississippi River. This will be done using innovative statistical techniques based on Bayesian methodologies. To date, The Missouri River Basin is the only major river headwaters in the western US for which reconstructions from tree rings have not been generated. This knowledge gap is critical given that the region is facing an array of water resources issues that are challenged by hydrologic variability-- both floods and droughts-- over just the past decades. Providing a longer context for understanding past variability of flow and climatic controls on it, particularly at decadal and longer time scales, is critical for anticipating and managing water supplies in the future. The Missouri River system is the life-blood of the American Midwest. The research team will collaborate with the US Army Corps of Engineers Institute of Water Resources and their Upper Missouri Basin Offices to develop and test scenarios of past tree-ring reconstructed river discharge that can be used for different aspects of the Corps' operations on the river system, leading to better multi-stakeholder discussions on how best to manage climate induced risk in the region. This direct engagement will enhance the application of the research products, as well as provide guidance for their design. To engage Montana water users in the headwaters region of the Missouri River Basin, the research team will convene a workshop for local, state, tribal, and national management agency personnel with the goal to build capacity to incorporate scientific information into planning and management. The research team will also partner with a new NSF EPSCoR project with a focus on Montana's vulnerability to climate change to produce a K-12 science module on water resources.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Missouri River system is the life-blood of the American Midwest providing water resources that drive agriculture, industry, hydroelectric power generation, and ecosystems. However, the Upper Missouri River Basin (UMRB) is the only major river system in the western U.S. for which hydrologic reconstructions from tree rings have not been generated in any systematic way. This knowledge gap is serious given that the region is facing an array of water resource issues that are challenged by recent hydrologic variability – both severe floods and droughts have occurred in the recent past and they could be reflecting larger scale changes in the global climate system. Based on a detailed study of the hydroclimatology of the overall Missouri River Basin (MRB) made as part of this project, these changes include a long-term trend toward decreasing flows from the UMRB to the Lower Basin, a reduction in snow versus rain fraction, and warming spring temperatures. Together, they suggest that the UMRB may less often provide important flow supplements to the Lower Basin in the future, perhaps as a consequence of climatic change. 

To provide a much-needed longer term context to the relatively short observed changes in hydroclimate since the early 20thcentury, this project developed very high quality reconstructions of water-year (October-September) total discharge for 31 streamflow gages in the UMRB using a newly developed network of annual tree-ring chronologies. These reconstructions cover the past millennium, thus greatly expanding our understanding of past natural streamflow variability prior to the 20thcentury and how it compares to more recent observed changes in runoff. They have been provided to water managers, scientists, and engineers working for the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), the U.S. Bureau of Reclamation (USBR), and the state of Montana Department of Natural Resources and Conservation (DNRC). In particular, the USBR is using the streamflow reconstructions for use in its RiverWare Operations Model to provide scenarios of future water availability and use so that informed decisions can be made about future use of UMRB discharge and adaptation to its possible changes. A data publication with tree-ring chronologies and streamflow gage reconstructions generated for use by this study is being published as a USGS data publication.

Because the Missouri River is so intensively used and relied upon by agriculture, industry, hydroelectric power generation, and ecosystems, an important component of this project was also to engage with regional water resource managers to ensure the products and information from this project were relevant and applicable to management and planning. Having as a collaborator the USGS located in Bozeman, MT in the UMRB was a key factor to the success in this regard. The timing of this project was also very fortuitous as interest in the basin, particularly related to water resource planning and climate adaptation, had just begun to gather steam around the onset of this project. Thus, beginning in 2015, the USGS began a collaboration with the USBR and the Montana DNRC to convene a group of UMRB water users and management agencies to discuss climate adaptation. This group, the Upper Missouri Basin Impacts Assessment Team, held bi-weekly phone calls with USGS personnel participating. USGS informed the group of the streamflow reconstructions being generated in this study, and contributed to discussions on the best uses of the paleohydrologic data in the assessment. This information was integrated into the paleohydrology sections of the water supply assessment portion of the overall impacts assessment and used in adaptation and tradeoff analyses in the Upper Missouri River Basin Impacts Assessment and Basin Study nearing publication.

Finally, this project has contributed greatly to the education and further career development of five graduate students and one post-doctoral fellow, thus expressing the importance of the educational component of this project.
